#Linear Regression Test:
##The reason behind applying LR test and what are the assumptions of applying such test:
#We assume the population of Covid-19 deaths are normal distributed.The samples are States of USA.The samples are randomly selected and indepenent.
#Linear Regression Model to see what independent variables related to COVID-19 deaths in the data set with alpha = 0.05. Since Pneumonia.Deaths and
#Influenza.Deaths are multicollineary(0.7919631). I aming to add the 2 columns as 1 new column: SUMP_I
#Only when all three categorical independent variables and SUMP_I together can get highest R-squared and adjusted R-squared values 
#We can apply Linear Regression Model to see which specific categories have significant information related to Covid-19 Deaths 
#We can get states of california,connecticut,florida, massachusetts, new jersey,new york city and texas have significant information to predict #Covid-19 Deaths
#Especially for california and new york city, both P-Value< 2e-16, have highest significant information to predict Covid-19 Deaths
#We can get age groups of 55-64 years, 65-74 years, 75-84 years and 85 years and over have significant information to predict Covid-19 Deaths
#Especially for 75-84 years, which P-Value=1.36e-07, has highest significant information to predict Covid-19 Deaths
#SUMP_I has significant information to predict Covid-19 Deaths, which P-Value< 2e-16, has highest significant information to predict Covid-19 Deaths
cleanSASFilter$SUMP_I <-rowSums(cbind(cleanSASFilter$Influenza.Deaths,cleanSASFilter$Pneumonia.Deaths))
cleanSASFilter
Lmodel<-lm(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths~cleanSASFilter$State+cleanSASFilter$Age.group+cleanSASFilter$Sex+cleanSASFilter$SUMP_I, data =cleanSASFilter)
Lmodel
#plot a numeric variable against a character variable
lattice::dotplot(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths~cleanSASFilter$State+cleanSASFilter$Age.group+cleanSASFilter$Sex+cleanSASFilter$SUMP_I, data =cleanSASFilter)
anova(Lmodel)
summary(Lmodel)
#Diagnostic Plots for Linear Regression Analysis: We can see that LR is not good way to do prediction for this dataset 
#Residuals vs Fitted.If residuals have non-linear patterns.If you find equally spread residuals around a horizontal line without distinct patterns, that is a good indication you don’t have non-linear relationships.
plot(Lmodel,1)
#Normal Q-Q:if residuals are normally distributed.It’s good if residuals are lined well on the straight dashed line
plot(Lmodel,2)
#Scale-Location.If residuals are spread equally along the ranges of predictors. Check the assumption of equal variance (homoscedasticity). It’s good if you see a horizontal line with equally (randomly) spread points.
plot(Lmodel,3)
#p-value < 2.2e-16. The model residuals are NOT normally distributes
aov_residualsL<-residuals(object=Lmodel)
aov_residualsL
shapiro.test(aov_residualsL)

Lmodel2way<-lm(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths~cleanSASFilter$State*cleanSASFilter$Sex+cleanSASFilter$State*cleanSASFilter$Age.group+cleanSASFilter$Age.group*cleanSASFilter$Sex, data =cleanSASFilter)

#Non-parametric Tests:
#The reason behind applying non-parametric test and what are the assumptions of applying such test: data not normaly distributed and sample size is small
#Because the data are not normally distributed so We are going to apply non-parametric measure to do the modelling to predict the results
#We first choose 2 groups of Wilcox rank test to predict the results
cleanSASUSAW<-cleanSAS[(cleanSAS$State=="united states" & (cleanSAS$Sex=="male" | cleanSAS$Sex=="female")),]
nrow(cleanSASUSAW)
cleanSASUSAW<-as.data.frame(cleanSASUSAW, stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
cleanSASUSAW
str(cleanSASUSAW)
par("mar")
par(mar=c(1,1,1,1))
#p-value = 0.0001223<0.05.The data is not normally distributed
shapiro.test(cleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths)
boxplot(cleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths, col = "orange",border = "brown",horizontal = F,notch = FALSE, main = "COVID.19.Deaths")
boxplot.stats(cleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths)
cor(cleanSASUSAW[4:8])
cleanSASUSAW$SUMP_I <-rowSums(cbind(cleanSASUSAW$Influenza.Deaths,cleanSASUSAW$Pneumonia.Deaths))
cleanSASUSAW
group_by(cleanSASUSAW, Sex) %>% summarise(count = n(),median = median(COVID.19.Deaths, na.rm = TRUE),IQR = IQR(COVID.19.Deaths, na.rm = TRUE))
#Apply non-paired 2 group wilcox rank test.p-value = 0.6933 > significance level alpha = 0.050. We can conclude that whole USA's female's death is NOT significantly different than male's death with a p-value = 0.6933.
wilcox.test(cleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths~cleanSASUSAW$Sex, paired=F, cleanSASUSAW, exact = FALSE, alternative = "two.sided")
#The sum of ranks of number of times female less than male is 67
sum(outer(female, male,"<"))
#The sum of ranks of number of times male less than female is 54
sum(outer(male, female,"<"))
#Dunn test is appropriate for groups with unequal numbers of observations:No significant differences.
PTD = dunnTest(COVID.19.Deaths ~ Age.group,data=cleanSASUSAW,method="bh")
PTD
cldList(comparison = PTD$Comparison,p.value= PTD$P.adj,threshold  = 0.05)
#Nemenyi test is appropriate for groups with equal numbers of observations:No significant differences
PTN = NemenyiTest(x = cleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Death,g = cleanSASUSAW$Age.group,dist="tukey")
PTN
cldList(comparison = PTN$Comparison,p.value = PTN$P.adj,threshold  = 0.05)
#P-value=0.69 >0.05. Also shows that whole USA's female's death is NOT significantly different than male's death  
pairwise.wilcox.test(cleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths, cleanSASUSAW$Sex, p.adjust.method = "BH")


#Apply 3 or more groups independent data of Kruskal-Wallis test to Age.group to see the results
group_by(cleanSASUSAW, Age.group) %>% summarise(count = n(),mean = mean(COVID.19.Deaths, na.rm = TRUE),sd = sd(COVID.19.Deaths, na.rm = TRUE),median = median(COVID.19.Deaths, na.rm = TRUE),IQR = IQR(COVID.19.Deaths, na.rm = TRUE))
#Since the data format is not suitable to do the Kruskal-Wallis test, I am going to redo the dataframe
KcleanSASUSAW<-split(cleanSASUSAW,cleanSASUSAW$Age.group)
KcleanSASUSAW
KcleanSASUSAW$`under 1 year`
mergedKcleanSASUSAW<-rbind(KcleanSASUSAW$`under 1 year`,KcleanSASUSAW$`1-4 years`,KcleanSASUSAW$`5-14 years`,KcleanSASUSAW$`15-24 years`, KcleanSASUSAW$`25-34 years`, KcleanSASUSAW$`35-44 years`, KcleanSASUSAW$`45-54 years`, KcleanSASUSAW$`55-64 years`, KcleanSASUSAW$`65-74 years`, KcleanSASUSAW$`75-84 years`, KcleanSASUSAW$`85 years and over`)
mergedKcleanSASUSAW
#each group has non-identical medians and means.
Summarize(COVID.19.Deaths~ Age.group,data = mergedKcleanSASUSAW) 
histogram(~ COVID.19.Deaths| Age.group, data=mergedKcleanSASUSAW,layout=c(1,11))
boxplot(COVID.19.Deaths ~ Age.group,data = mergedKcleanSASUSAW,ylab="COVID.19.Deaths",xlab="Age.group")
#As the p-value=0.02534 is less than the significance level 0.05, we can conclude that there are significant differences between the treatment groups.
##From the output of the Kruskal-Wallis test, we know that there is a significant difference between groups, but we don’t know which pairs of groups are different
kruskal.test(mergedKcleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths ~ mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group, data = mergedKcleanSASUSAW)
#Dunn test is appropriate for groups with unequal numbers of observations:No significant differences.
PTD = dunnTest(COVID.19.Deaths ~ Age.group,data=mergedKcleanSASUSAW,method="bh")
PTD
cldList(comparison = PTD$Comparison,p.value= PTD$P.adj,threshold  = 0.05)
#Nemenyi test is appropriate for groups with equal numbers of observations:No significant differences
PTN = NemenyiTest(x = mergedKcleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Death,g = mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group,dist="tukey")
PTN
cldList(comparison = PTN$Comparison,p.value = PTN$P.adj,threshold  = 0.05)
#Mann–Whitney U-tests.  To prevent the inflation of type I error rates, adjustments to the p-values can be made using the p.adjust.method option to control the familywise error rate or to control the false discovery rate
PTP =pairwise.wilcox.test(mergedKcleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths, mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group, p.adjust.method = "none")
PTP 
PTP = PTP$p.value
PTP
PTP1 = fullPTable(PTP)
PTP1
#Values sharing the same letter are not significantly different: All group ranges have no significant differences
multcompLetters(PTP1, compare="<", threshold=0.05,Letters=letters,reversed = FALSE)
